gov.nasa.larcfm.Util

Class PolyPath

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.nasa.larcfm.Util.PolyPath
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ErrorReporter

    public class PolyPath
extends java.lang.Object
implements ErrorReporter
    Polygons are arranged in "paths" similar to aircraft plans (and, in fact, this object can produce one -- or more -- faux-aircraft plans that approximate the area in question). The polygon is allowed to change shape as it travels along the path, but the number of vertices must remain constant. The shape at non-specified time points is linearly interpolated from the neighboring points. Paths with a single entry (at any time) are considered to be static, immobile polygons that exist at all times Paths can have one of 3 modes: MORPHING (the default): all polygons must have the same number of vertices. Velocities are calculated by vertex between consecutive steps. AVG_VEL: Velocities are calculated between the average points of consecutive steps. Polygons do not need to have the same number of vertices at each step. USER_VEL: Velocities are user-specified and applied to all vertices. Polygons do not need to have the same number of vertices at each step. The last step will have an infinitely continuing velocity. USER_VEL_FINITE: As USER_VEL, but the path does not continue past the last step. (One-step paths are considered the same as USER_VEL.) The last step is mostly ignored except for time and can be any polygon. Note: polygon support is experimental and the interface is subject to change!

        tend - end time of path (absolute)

      • buildPlan

        public Triple<Plan,java.lang.Double,java.lang.Double> buildPlan()

        Returns:
        new Plan, radius, height

      • isLatLon

        public boolean isLatLon()
        Return true if this path contains any geodetic points.

      • isStatic

        public boolean isStatic()
        Return true if this PolyPath is static (it always exists in a fixed location). This is the case if there is only one step in the path and the mode is not USER_VEL

      • isContinuing

        public boolean isContinuing()
        Return true if this PolyPath continues to exist past the defined path (it has a velocity, which may be zero, and no definite end point) This is the case if mode is USER_VEL or if there is only one step in the path.

      • getPathMode

        public PolyPath.PathMode getPathMode()
        Get the mode for this path. MORPHING: all polygons must have the same number of vertices. Velocities are calculated by vertex between consecutive steps. AVG_VEL: Velocities are calculated between the average points of consecutive steps. Polygons do not need to have the same number of vertices at each step. USER_VEL: Velocities are user-specified and applied to all vertices. Polygons do not need to have the same number of vertices at each step. The last step will have an infinitely continuing velocity.

      • setPathMode

        public void setPathMode(PolyPath.PathMode m)
        Set the mode for this path. MORPHING: all polygons must have the same number of vertices. Velocities are calculated by vertex between consecutive steps. AVG_VEL: Velocities are calculated between the average points of consecutive steps. Polygons do not need to have the same number of vertices at each step. USER_VEL: Velocities are user-specified and applied to all vertices. Polygons do not need to have the same number of vertices at each step. The last step will have an infinitely continuing velocity. Changing away from USER_VEL will erase any stored velocity information. Changing to USER_VEL will populate the path with the same values as AVG_VEL (the last step will have a zero velocity). USER_VEL_FINITE: as USER_VEL

        public java.lang.String getName()

        public double getFirstTime()
        Returns the start time of this path. Static paths have a start time of 0.

      • getLastTime

        public double getLastTime()
        Returns the end time of this path. Static paths have an end time of 0. Continuing paths have an end time of POSITIVE_INFINITY

      • getIndex

        public int getIndex(double time)
        Returns the step index associated with a particular time, if there is a match, otherwise returns a negative value. -1 indicates a time before the path begins. -x indicates a time after point (x-1), so a time between points 1 and 2 will return index -2. A time after the path will return -size-1.

      • getPolyRef

        public SimplePoly getPolyRef(int n)
        Returns the poly at step index n (reference).

      • validate

        public boolean validate()
        Returns true if the polypath follows expected behaviors (i.e. increasing times and same size for each MORPHING poly). Otherwise this sets error messages.

      • truncate

        public PolyPath truncate(double t)
        Return a truncated version of this path that ends at time t. This will change a USER_VEL path into a USER_VEL_FINITE path.
        Parameters:
        t - The time to halt the path.
        Returns:
        A truncated path. If t <= the path's start time, then return an empty path. If t >= the path's end time, then return a copy of the original path.

      • addVertex

        public void addVertex(Position p,
                      double top,
                      double time)
        A quick and dirty method for building paths one point at a time. This does not check that there are the same number of points at each step -- call validate() on this object when done to confirm that the final path is correct.
        Parameters:
        p - A new (bottom) point.
        top - p's corresponding top altitude
        time - the time for the poly p is a vertex of

      • addVertex

        public void addVertex(int n,
                      Position p)
        This adds a vertex to every polygon on this path. The vertex will be added relative to the centroid in each case, so other polygons may need to be modified to match.
        Parameters:
        p -

      • removeVertex

        public void removeVertex(int vert)
        Remove the nth vertex from all polygons on the path.
        Parameters:

      • timeshift

        public void timeshift(double shift)
        Shift all times in the path by the given number of seconds.
        Parameters:
        shift - Amount of shift.

      • getSegment

        public int getSegment(double tm)
        Return the segment number that contains 'time' in [s]. If the time is not contained in the flight plan then -1 is returned. If the time for point 1 is 10.0 and the time for point 2 is 20.0, then getSegment(10.0) will produce 0, getSegment(15.0) will produce 0, and getSegment(20.0) will produce 1.

      • getMessage

        public java.lang.String getMessage()
        Description copied from interface: ErrorReporter
        Return a string representation of any errors or warnings. Calling this method will clear any messages and reset both the error and warning status to none.
        Specified by:

        Returns:
        error and warning messages. If there are no messages, an empty string is returned.

      • getMessageNoClear

        public java.lang.String getMessageNoClear()
        Description copied from interface: ErrorReporter
        Return a string representation of any errors or warnings. Calling this method will not clear the error or warning status (i.e., hasError() will return the same value before and after this call.)
        Specified by:
        getMessageNoClear in interface ErrorReporter
        Returns:
        error and warning messages. If there are no messages, an empty string is returned.
